title: Signal in the Code
text:
Welcome ğŸ‘‹






Twelve years ago, two researchers proposed a provocative idea: that the genetic code may carry an embedded signal of non-evolutionary origin.
Their work sparked intrigue â€” and resistance.
This book revisits the findings of V.Â shâ€™Cherbak and M.Â Makukov with a fresh perspective and a new approach. As a seasoned software engineer and independent researcher in data science and bioinformatics, I present compelling new evidence â€” evidence that fills a critical gap in their theory and, I argue, settles the case for an embedded signal in the genetic code once and for all.
Whether youâ€™re a scientist, skeptic, or simply curious â€” I invite you to examine the signal for yourself.

title: Preface
text:
In 2013, two Kazakh researchers from Al-Farabi Kazakh National University â€” biologist Vladimir shCherbak and astronomer Maxim Makukov â€” published a paper titled â€œThe â€˜Wow! signalâ€™ of the terrestrial genetic codeâ€ in Icarus, a peer-reviewed journal focused on planetary science and Solar System research. In their 15-page paper, spanning over 15,000 words, they claimed to have discovered an embedded signal within the genetic makeup of life on Earth. While their hypothesis drew immediate attention in fringe Reddit communities and even made appearances on television shows, it was swiftly dismissed by the mainstream scientific community. Terms like â€œnumerologyâ€ and â€œbogus scienceâ€ were among the more charitable labels applied to their work.
Their decision to condense years of research into a single, dense article led M. Makukov to expand on their ideas through additional channels. He launched a dedicated website, produced explanatory videos on Youtube, and hosted a public Ask Me Anything (AMA) session on Reddit titled â€œScience AMA Series: Iâ€™m Maxim Makukov, a researcher in astrobiology and astrophysics and a co-author of the papers which claim to have identified extraterrestrial signal in the universal genetic code thereby confirming directed panspermia. AMA!â€.
The session quickly turned into a heated debate between supporters and skeptics.
In a follow-up article, â€œSETI in vivo: testing the we-are-them hypothesisâ€, published in the International Journal of Astrobiology in April 2018, the authors addressed critical questions raised after their initial publication and attempted a more cautious, scientifically grounded approach. Despite their efforts, their work was once again met with ridicule, and the broader scientific reception remained dismissive.
Later that year, Vladimir shâ€™Cherbak sadly passed away 1, and his former student, Maxim, shifted his academic focus toward cosmology.
1Â Check dateBut were they right?






The aim of this book is to demonstrate, beyond any reasonable doubt, that shâ€™Cherbak and Makukov were fundamentally correct in their theory. However, I believe they overlooked a crucial piece of the puzzle that would have made their case easier to explain and defend. It took me twelve years of working in information and data science, along with focused training in mathematics, bioinformatics, and genetic data analysis, to uncover that missing piece.



To the two researchers who led me down this rabbit hole â€” and made sure I didnâ€™t come back the same.

title: Foundations
text:
â€DNA is like a computer program but far, far more advanced than any software ever created.â€


Bill Gates, The Road Ahead

title: Final Thought
text:
â€œYouâ€™re wondering who we are, why we have done this, how it has come that I stand before you, the image of a being from so long ago. Life evolved on my planet before all others in this part of the galaxy. We left our world, explored the stars, and found none like ourselves. Our civilisation thrived for ages, but what is the life of one race, compared to the vast stretches of cosmic time? We knew that one day we would be gone, that nothing of us would survive. So, we left you. Our scientists seeded the primordial oceans of many worlds, where life was in its infancy. The seed codes directed your evolution toward a physical form resembling ours. This body you see before you, which is, of course, shaped as yours is shaped, for you are the end result. The seed codes also contained this message, which we scattered in fragments on many different worlds. It was our hope that you would have to come together in fellowship and companionship to hear this message. And if you can see and hear me, our hope has been fulfilled. You are a monument, not to our greatness, but to our existence. That was our wish, that you too would know life, and would keep alive our memory. There is something of us in each of you, and so, something of you in each other. Remember us.â€


Humanoid in â€œThe Chaseâ€, Star Trek: The Next Generation

title: Preface
text:
In 2013, two Kazakh researchers from Al-Farabi Kazakh National University â€” biologist Vladimir shCherbak and astronomer Maxim Makukov â€” published a paper titled â€œThe â€˜Wow! signalâ€™ of the terrestrial genetic codeâ€ in Icarus, a peer-reviewed journal focused on planetary science and Solar System research. In their 15-page paper, spanning over 15,000 words, they claimed to have discovered an embedded signal within the genetic makeup of life on Earth. While their hypothesis drew immediate attention in fringe Reddit communities and even made appearances on television shows, it was swiftly dismissed by the mainstream scientific community. Terms like â€œnumerologyâ€ and â€œbogus scienceâ€ were among the more charitable labels applied to their work.
Their decision to condense years of research into a single, dense article led M. Makukov to expand on their ideas through additional channels. He launched a dedicated website, produced explanatory videos on Youtube, and hosted a public Ask Me Anything (AMA) session on Reddit titled â€œScience AMA Series: Iâ€™m Maxim Makukov, a researcher in astrobiology and astrophysics and a co-author of the papers which claim to have identified extraterrestrial signal in the universal genetic code thereby confirming directed panspermia. AMA!â€.
The session quickly turned into a heated debate between supporters and skeptics.
In a follow-up article, â€œSETI in vivo: testing the we-are-them hypothesisâ€, published in the International Journal of Astrobiology in April 2018, the authors addressed critical questions raised after their initial publication and attempted a more cautious, scientifically grounded approach. Despite their efforts, their work was once again met with ridicule, and the broader scientific reception remained dismissive.
Later that year, Vladimir shâ€™Cherbak sadly passed away 1, and his former student, Maxim, shifted his academic focus toward cosmology.
1Â Check dateBut were they right?






The aim of this book is to demonstrate, beyond any reasonable doubt, that shâ€™Cherbak and Makukov were fundamentally correct in their theory. However, I believe they overlooked a crucial piece of the puzzle that would have made their case easier to explain and defend. It took me twelve years of working in information and data science, along with focused training in mathematics, bioinformatics, and genetic data analysis, to uncover that missing piece.



To the two researchers who led me down this rabbit hole â€” and made sure I didnâ€™t come back the same.
